verses.text: LORD, do not rebuke me in Your anger, nor discipline me in Your wrath.
verses.comment: David pleads for moderation in God's chastisement, recognizing His Fatherly discipline (cf. Heb. 12:5-6). In Catholic tradition, this echoes the concept of temporal punishment and the need for God's mercy beyond strict justice.

verses.text: Show mercy to me, LORD, for I am weak; heal me, LORD, for my bones are trembling.
verses.comment: The appeal for healing includes both physical and spiritual distress. The language foreshadows Christ as the ultimate healer (cf. Matt. 9:12–13), a key theme in Catholic sacramental theology (see Anointing of the Sick).

verses.text: My soul is greatly shaken; but You, LORD—how long?
verses.comment: David voices the classic lament, 'How long?'—a prayer found throughout the Psalms. The Catholic liturgy preserves this tone of trust in suffering, integrating body and soul.

verses.text: Return, LORD, deliver my soul; save me because of Your steadfast love.
verses.comment: The 'steadfast love' (Hebrew: 'hesed') is God’s covenant loyalty—a foundation of Catholic soteriology emphasizing grace through God's faithful promises and the means of salvation provided in the Church.

verses.text: For in death there is no remembrance of You; in Sheol, who will give You thanks?
verses.comment: The ancient Hebrew view sees Sheol as a place where praise is absent. Christian (and specifically Catholic) theology understands this lament in light of Christ’s victory over death (cf. 2 Tim. 1:10) and the Communion of Saints, emphasizing prayers for the dead.

verses.text: I am weary with my groaning; all night I flood my bed with weeping, I drench my couch with tears.
verses.comment: An intense description of sorrow, often read allegorically in patristic tradition as repentance for sin—a key Catholic theme in the Sacrament of Confession.

verses.text: My eye has grown dim with grief; it grows weak because of all my enemies.
verses.comment: Sorrows seen through the eyes echo Jesus' lament over Jerusalem (Luke 19:41). The Catholic devotional practice of weeping for sin ('gift of tears') has precedent in this verse.

verses.text: Away from me, all you who do evil, for the LORD has heard the sound of my weeping.
verses.comment: Jesus quotes this wording in Matthew 7:23 and Luke 13:27, linking David’s prayer with Christ’s own authoritative teaching. The theme of separation from evil aligns with the Catholic understanding of purification (cf. Purgatory).

verses.text: The LORD has heard my plea, the LORD accepts my prayer.
verses.comment: Confidence in answered prayer demonstrates faith in God’s fatherly care. Catholic tradition encourages both personal and communal prayer (cf. intercession through saints).

verses.text: All my enemies will be ashamed and greatly troubled; they will turn back and be put to shame in a moment.
verses.comment: God's vindication points forward to the final judgment. The certainty of God’s justice is affirmed in both Testaments and underlines the eschatological hope deeply rooted in Catholic teaching.
